com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state

Class BaseGamestate<T extends IGameScene>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.BaseGamestate<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IGameState, ITypedGameState<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ConsoleGamestate, DefaultGamestate, EngineGamestate, InitialGamestate, LocalMapGamestate, UserGamestate

    @RequiresInjection
public class BaseGamestate<T extends IGameScene>
extends Object
implements ITypedGameState<T>
    Use as the base for game states.

    Notes:

    - Base dependencies will be injected, see #injectBaseDependencies.
    - State dependencies need to be set via setters or initStateDependencies(com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.render.IGameStateRenderer, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IGameStateInputHandler, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IControlScheme, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IControlHandler), or they will default to empty implementations.
    - State dependencies will also have the gamestate injected when set, if they use InjectGameState. To use this feature with other dependencies, see getGamestateInjector().
    - Inject your own dependencies by using Inject.
    - If needed there are hooks for afterInitBaseDependencies() and afterInitStateDependencies().
    - Override getSceneControl() to return your custom scene control and use the helper #assignSceneGeneric.
    - Override #getTag() and return your own tag to trace logs to the actual gamestate implementation.
    - The default onRender() implementation will draw using getRenderOrder().

    • Constructor Detail

      • BaseGamestate

        @Inject
protected BaseGamestate()
        Default constructor.

        The scene type will be resolved from this state's type.

        For example the state below will have the scene type ICustomGamescene.
        public CustomGamestate extends BaseGamestate<ICustomGamescene>

        You can also create instances of generic states with the use of anonymous subclasses (note the curly braces a the end).
        BaseGamestateICustomGamescene gamestate = new BaseGamestateICustomGamescene() { };

        Be aware that the scene type must be fully resolved for this to work.
        The following will not work because the actual type of T (T is a type variable) will not be known at runtime.
        BaseGamestateT gamestate = new BaseGamestateT() { };

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the scene type cannot be fully resolved.

      • BaseGamestate

        public BaseGamestate(TypeToken<T> sceneTypeToken)
        Public constructor with a scene type token.

        Use this to create instances of generic states dynamically and without the use of an anonymous subclass for the state.
        Instead of the scene type being resolved from the context, it will be stored in the TypeToken that was given.

        For example below we instantiate a state directly by passing it a new TypeToken. We don't have to create the TypeToken right there, it could have come from somewhere else too.
        BaseGamestateICustomGamescene gamestate = new BaseGamestateICustomGamescene(new TypeTokenICustomGamescene() { });

        Be aware that the scene type must be fully resolved for this to work.
        The following will not work because the actual type of T (T is a type variable) will not be known at runtime.
        BaseGamestateT gamestate = new BaseGamestateT(new TypeTokenT() { });

        Parameters:
        sceneTypeToken - The type token that should be used for the scene type.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the scene type cannot be fully resolved.

      • BaseGamestate

        public BaseGamestate(Class<T> sceneTypeClass)
        Public constructor with a scene type class.

        Use this to create instances of generic gamestate types.

        Parameters:
        sceneTypeClass - The class that should be used for the scene type.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the scene type cannot be fully resolved.

      • BaseGamestate

        protected BaseGamestate(IGameStateRenderer defaultRender,
                        IGameStateInputHandler defaultInputHandler,
                        IControlScheme defaultControlScheme,
                        IControlHandler defaultControlHandler)
        Constructor with optional state parameters.

        You can pass any objects you'd like to assign. Null values are permitted for all values except the scene type.

        Note: Injected base objects like the context will not be available at this point.

        Useful for custom constructor injection, for manual creation see initStateDependencies(com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.render.IGameStateRenderer, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IGameStateInputHandler, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IControlScheme, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IControlHandler).
        Alternatively you can use method injection, which will be called after base injection has happened.

        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If sceneType is null.

      • BaseGamestate

        protected BaseGamestate(javax.inject.Provider<? extends T> defaultSceneProvider,
                        IGameSceneControl.IModifiableGameSceneControl<T> defaultSceneControl)
        Constructor with optional scene type parameters.

        You can pass any objects you'd like to assign. Null values are permitted for all values except the scene type.

        Note: Injected base objects like the context will not be available at this point.

        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If sceneType is null.

      • initStateDependencies

        protected void initStateDependencies(IGameStateRenderer defaultRender,
                                     IGameStateInputHandler defaultInputHandler,
                                     IControlScheme defaultControlScheme,
                                     IControlHandler defaultControlHandler)
        Initializes the state dependencies. Override this method to pass custom state objects.

        If any state objects have been set before this call (ex. in the constructor), those will be passed here as parameters.

        This method will be called during injectDependencies(com.tokelon.toktales.tools.core.inject.parameter.IParameterInjector.IParameterInjectorFactory, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.integration.IGameStateIntegrator.IGameStateIntegratorFactory, com.tokelon.toktales.core.render.order.IRenderOrder, com.tokelon.toktales.core.engine.IEngineContext, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IGameStateInput, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.scene.IGameSceneControl.IGameSceneControlFactory, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.render.IGameStateRenderer, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IGameStateInputHandler, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IControlScheme, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IControlHandler), after initBaseDependencies(com.tokelon.toktales.core.engine.IEngineContext, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IGameStateInput, javax.inject.Provider<? extends T>, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.scene.IGameSceneControl.IModifiableGameSceneControl<T>) and afterInitBaseDependencies(), so the context and any other injected objects will have their injected values.

        See Also:
        afterInitStateDependencies()

      • afterInitStateDependencies

        protected void afterInitStateDependencies()
        Called after state dependencies have been initialized.

        The default implementation for this will:
        - Register the state input handler given by getStateInputHandler(), to the state input given by getStateInput() by calling IGameStateInputHandler.register(IGameStateInput).

        See Also:
        initStateDependencies(com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.render.IGameStateRenderer, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IGameStateInputHandler, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IControlScheme, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IControlHandler)

      • afterInjectDependencies

        protected void afterInjectDependencies()
        Called after injectDependencies(com.tokelon.toktales.tools.core.inject.parameter.IParameterInjector.IParameterInjectorFactory, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.integration.IGameStateIntegrator.IGameStateIntegratorFactory, com.tokelon.toktales.core.render.order.IRenderOrder, com.tokelon.toktales.core.engine.IEngineContext, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IGameStateInput, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.scene.IGameSceneControl.IGameSceneControlFactory, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.render.IGameStateRenderer, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IGameStateInputHandler, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IControlScheme, com.tokelon.toktales.core.game.state.IControlHandler) has run (at the end of it).         protected boolean atSetupInitialGamescene()
        Creates and assigns the initial gamescene to this state's scene control.

        Uses createInitialScene() to create the initial scene.

      • onSurfaceCreated

        protected void onSurfaceCreated(ISurface surface)
        Called when a surface is created.

        The default implementation saves the first surface that is created and sets it as current. The surface will remain the current as long as it is not destroyed.

        Parameters:
        surface -
        See Also:
        ISurfaceCallback#surfaceCreated(ISurface)}

      • onSurfaceChanged

        protected void onSurfaceChanged(ISurface surface)
        Called when a surface is changed.

        The implementation should test whether the given surface is the current one with getCurrentSurface().

        The default implementation does nothing.

        Parameters:
        surface -
        See Also:
        ISurfaceCallback#surfaceChanged(ISurface)}

      • onSurfaceDestroyed

        protected void onSurfaceDestroyed(ISurface surface)
        Called when a surface is destroyed.

        The implementation should test whether the given surface is the current one with getCurrentSurface().

        The default implementation sets the surface returned by getCurrentSurface() to null if it's equal the given one.

        Parameters:
        surface -
        See Also:
        ISurfaceCallback#surfaceDestroyed(ISurface)}

      • assignScene

        public boolean assignScene(String name,
                           IGameScene scene)
        Assigns a scene to this state with the given name.

        The scene must be compatible with this state, in that it must match the type this state expects.

        The default implementation checks if the scene is an instance of this state's scene type, and if yes calls assignSceneTyped(String, IGameScene).
        Note that the type check will not consider any generic parts, if you need that use assignSceneCustom(String, IGameSceneAssignment).

        Specified by:
        assignScene in interface IGameState
        Returns:
        True if the given scene was assigned successfully, false if not.

      • assignSceneCustom

        public boolean assignSceneCustom(String name,
                                 IGameSceneAssignment sceneAssignment)
        Assigns a scene using a scene assignment parameter.

        Returns whether the scene was actually assigned or not.

        The default implementation checks if the assignment scene is of type of this state's scene type, and if yes calls assignSceneTyped(String, IGameScene).
        Note that if the scene assignment returns true for the type check, it will try to cast the scene to this state's scene type. If the cast fails it will throw an IllegalArgumentException.

        You can use this method to make type checks that respect generic types, using something like GenericGamesceneAssignment.

        Specified by:
        assignSceneCustom in interface IGameState
        Returns:
        True if the given scene was successfully assigned, false if not.

      • assignSceneTyped

        public boolean assignSceneTyped(String name,
                                T scene)
        Description copied from interface: ITypedGameState
        Assigns a scene in a type safe matter, since the scene's type must match this state's scene type.

        Returns whether the scene was actually assigned or not.

        Specified by:
        assignSceneTyped in interface ITypedGameState<T extends IGameScene>
        Returns:
        True if the given scene was assigned successfully, false if not.

        Specified by:

      • getStateInput

        public IGameStateInput getStateInput()
        Description copied from interface: IGameState
        The state input is a manager that collects input handlers, and notifies them when new events happen.

        The implementation is platform specific and provides extended functionality to register callbacks.

        Specified by:
        getStateInput in interface IGameState
        Returns:
        The state input.

      • getStateInputHandler

        public IGameStateInputHandler getStateInputHandler()
        Description copied from interface: IGameState
        The state input handler is the default way of processing state related events, and transforming them into actions on the gamestate or gamescene.

        The following details the expected workflow:
        1. A state and platform dependent input handler is implemented and set on this state.
        2. The input handler is registered at the state input.
        3. The input handler receives inputs and uses the control scheme to process them to actions.
        4. The input handler passes the actions to the control handler.


        Notes:
        1. Sometimes you will want to implement state specific input handler, control scheme and control handler. In those cases you can override these methods to return your state specific types.
        Specified by:
        getStateInputHandler in interface IGameState
        Returns:
        The state input handler.

      • getStateControlScheme

        public IControlScheme getStateControlScheme()
        Description copied from interface: IGameState
        The control scheme provides a mapping from inputs to actions, and is used by the state input handler for this reason.

        It is state and platform dependent.
        Specified by:
        getStateControlScheme in interface IGameState
        Returns:
        The state control scheme.

      • getStateControlHandler

        public IControlHandler getStateControlHandler()
        Description copied from interface: IGameState
        The control handler handles all actions it is given, and is normally used by the state input handler for this reason.

        Note that state handler should first call the scene handler to make scene specific handling possible.
        Specified by:
        getStateControlHandler in interface IGameState
        Returns:
        The state control handler.

      • setStateRenderer

        protected void setStateRenderer(IGameStateRenderer renderer)
        Sets the state render.

        If supported this gamestate will be injected via InjectGameState.

        The given render will be registered as a ISurfaceManager.ISurfaceCallback and the previous render will be unregistered.

        Parameters:
        renderer -
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If renderer is null.
